Story #3

  • March 04, 2021
  • Zizi

I was good at creating art and drawing. I could sit busy for hours and I loved it. My mother did a superb job providing the best materials she can buy for me. One year my teachers decided to put me in the competition, so I was working hard for a full year getting all different kinds of art ready. When all works were ready the teachers were satisfied. But one day I came into a drawing school classroom and found all my works in a dirty corner not needed. The teachers made a decision to send their daughter’s works instead. It was clear enough that the quality of work did not play any role in this completion between me and her.

This situation was a big hit for me. The school was my favourite place to come. Sometimes I got words of praise, quite often the teacher was reading a book to us, and it was a calm place where I can create something and share my point of view. I was so carefully working hard at every piece for that big competition and then I found it was not needed and stored in a dirty corner. I left the school and never came back. My mother did not work hard on figuring out what happened. I loved the place so much and then one day said “I’m not going there again.” Sounds pretty unusual. Don’t you think?

That might seems like a small thing but for some reason that shut my desire to draw totally even nowadays. That was the first time my creation was denied.

When I was 14 I wanted to go to a dance school. I was serious enough to go to live in another city with my friend to attend a dance collage, but my mother said: “No”. Check my mom’s rule number three. In short, you do what she says without asking or complaining. And what can you really do without monetary support? A couple of years later I was dancing with a guy at a house party. We were both drunk, and he decided to make a twist, and we made it except my right knee. It was not in good time, so I tore something in my knee, got caught into a cast for two months and never get recovered from it. So if I go now in almost any dancing class I will walk out in ten minutes laming. Yoga is the only space where I don’t feel like a cripple. I have great flexibility, so I feel at home with it. The dancing door was closed forever.

In the university I loved dancing and clubs, so I dreamed to be a DJ. I learned how to create music on the computer in Fl Studio and started to create my own drum’n’bass tracks. I went to a DJ school and I heard everything right and did a great job, that was so much fun. But my best friend Veronica came there with me. And unfortunately she was really weak on this. We both graduated, and I was invited to work in our favorite club with my favorite DJ who promised to help me with everything. That was all I dreamed about, but Veronica said if I will accept it she will stop communicating with me. I was stupid enough to refuse this opportunity, and she stopped communicating with me anyways after less than a month. She just left the university group we were in to another one and never talked to me again. That jealousy did not allow her to stay by my side.

I lost my previous best friend quite the same way. We got in a company and one guy was flirting with her, which was pretty unusual. I made my boyfriend to tell me the truth why this guy is doing it, because she was far from a good-looking girl. He said that the guy was going to push her to have sex, and then he would immediately leave her. I told my friend everything I learned, but she said “I’m jealous of her success” and I did not call her the next day so did not she. Nastya was my best friend since I was 8 or 9. There was a company of girls in our apartment building and suddenly one of the girls told the others some lies about me. So everyone stopped communicating with me except Nastya. My mom figured out that somehow, because I never snitched, and made the girl to resolve this issue.

Nastya was the one who made me smoking when I was 14 even against the promise to my mother. When I was in a second grade two girls stole money from their mother’s wallets and bought the whole class sweets and chips. They got caught and everyone in a class was obliged to make a promise to a parent. So my promise was “I will never smoke”. Everyone knew about it, so if anyone suggested me a cigarettе, it was good enough to tell about the promise. Anyways, when I was 14, Nastya said one day: “try to smoke with me, or I will stop communicating with you”. As a stupid friend I agreed to try it and broke my promise. After that I was smoking for 10 years. I was spending my money for food at school on cigarettes and stayed hungry till I got home.

The 10-year smoking thing finally got resolution in one of my mushroom’s trips. I was the one who did not like to depend on anything, so I was always attentive not to get addicted to anything. But the cigarettes and some spiritual connection with them was so strong. I fully believed I could not stop it. But mushrooms showed me that this was not true. I was in a forest with my friends. I was sitting on a tree and suddenly realized: ”I am in a trip for 6 hours and I have not had a single cigarette!” That was an amazing discovery. Next day I was walking in the street and lit a cigarette as I often did and a huge wave of shame covered me. “What am I doing poisoning myself and others? Harming myself and others”. I threw the cigarette away and started researching how to stop smoking. I asked my friends and a girl recommended me a book “Easy way to stop smoking” by Allen Carr. It took me two days to finish it. It was a boring repetition of the same idea and my friend told me: “Remember! The key thing from it is a final decision. You should make a final decision to stop”. I don’t really know if Allen is writing about it in his book. But I stopped smoking right when I finished reading the book. So it was unexpectedly easy. Ten years of smoking, two days of reading and a final decision. I stopped smoking and never started again.
